questions.text: A 45-day old infant developed icterus and two days later symptoms and signs of acute liver failure appeared. Child was found to be positive for HbsAg. The mother was also HbsAg carrier. The mother's hepatitis B serological profile is likely to be:

options.label: C
options.text: HbsAg and anti Hbe antibody positivity

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • HbsAg and HbeAg positivity (Answer B): The presence of both Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) in the mother indicates an active HBV infection with high infectivity. HBeAg is a marker of high levels of viral replication and therefore high infectivity. Vertical transmission (from mother to child) of hepatitis B is highly likely when the mother is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive. The infant’s development of acute liver failure is consistent with a high viral load transmission, which is more likely in the setting of maternal HBeAg positivity. HbsAg positive only (Answer A): While being positive for HBsAg indicates that the mother is a carrier of hepatitis B, the absence of HBeAg would suggest a lower level of infectivity. However, this scenario is less consistent with the infant's severe presentation. HbsAg and anti-HBe antibody positivity (Answer C): The presence of anti-HBe antibodies along with HBsAg suggests a lower level of viral replication and hence a lower infectivity compared to the presence of HBeAg. This profile is less likely in a case where vertical transmission has led to acute liver failure in the infant. Mother infected with mutant HBV (Answer D): While mutations in the HBV genome can occur, leading to changes in the expression of HBeAg (e.g., the "precore mutant"), this option does not provide enough specific information to be the most likely answer in this context.
  • • HbsAg and HbeAg positivity (Answer B): The presence of both Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and Hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg) in the mother indicates an active HBV infection with high infectivity. HBeAg is a marker of high levels of viral replication and therefore high infectivity. Vertical transmission (from mother to child) of hepatitis B is highly likely when the mother is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive. The infant’s development of acute liver failure is consistent with a high viral load transmission, which is more likely in the setting of maternal HBeAg positivity.

  • • HbsAg and anti-HBe antibody positivity (Answer C): The presence of anti-HBe antibodies along with HBsAg suggests a lower level of viral replication and hence a lower infectivity compared to the presence of HBeAg. This profile is less likely in a case where vertical transmission has led to acute liver failure in the infant.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the clinic with a 6-month history of increasing fatigue, weight gain primarily around the abdomen, and difficulty sleeping. She also reports her skin has become very thin and bruises easily. On physical examination, she has a rounded face, increased fat deposition in the cervical spine area and purple striae on her abdomen. Blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg. Laboratory tests show hyperglycemia and hypokalemia. A 24-hour urinary free cortisol test indicates elevated levels of cortisol. Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cushing Syndrome (Answer B) : The patient presents with several classic signs and symptoms of Cushing Syndrome. These include: Centripetal obesity : Weight gain primarily around the abdomen. Skin changes : Thin skin that bruises easily and purple striae (stretch marks) are typical manifestations of Cushing Syndrome. Facial changes : A rounded face is often described as a "moon face". Fat deposition : Increased fat in the cervical spine area, known as a ‘buffalo hump’. Hypertension and hyperglycemia : Common consequences of chronic exposure to high levels of cortisol. Elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol : This laboratory finding confirms the presence of excess cortisol, a hallmark of Cushing Syndrome. Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (Answer A) : While PCOS can be associated with obesity and menstrual irregularities, it does not typically present with the specific cushingoid features (such as easy bruising, skin thinning, and purple striae) or elevated cortisol levels. Adrenal Insufficiency (Answer C) : This condition is characterized by a deficiency in cortisol production, which contrasts with the elevated cortisol levels seen in this patient. Adrenal insufficiency typically presents with symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and low blood pressure. Primary Aldosteronism (Answer D) : This condition typically presents with hypertension and hypokalemia, but it is not associated with the cushingoid features or elevated cortisol levels found in this patient.
  • • Cushing Syndrome (Answer B) : The patient presents with several classic signs and symptoms of Cushing Syndrome. These include: Centripetal obesity : Weight gain primarily around the abdomen. Skin changes : Thin skin that bruises easily and purple striae (stretch marks) are typical manifestations of Cushing Syndrome. Facial changes : A rounded face is often described as a "moon face". Fat deposition : Increased fat in the cervical spine area, known as a ‘buffalo hump’. Hypertension and hyperglycemia : Common consequences of chronic exposure to high levels of cortisol. Elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol : This laboratory finding confirms the presence of excess cortisol, a hallmark of Cushing Syndrome.
  • • Cushing Syndrome (Answer B)
  • • Centripetal obesity : Weight gain primarily around the abdomen. Skin changes : Thin skin that bruises easily and purple striae (stretch marks) are typical manifestations of Cushing Syndrome. Facial changes : A rounded face is often described as a "moon face". Fat deposition : Increased fat in the cervical spine area, known as a ‘buffalo hump’. Hypertension and hyperglycemia : Common consequences of chronic exposure to high levels of cortisol. Elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol : This laboratory finding confirms the presence of excess cortisol, a hallmark of Cushing Syndrome.
  • • Centripetal obesity : Weight gain primarily around the abdomen.
  • • Centripetal obesity
  • • Skin changes : Thin skin that bruises easily and purple striae (stretch marks) are typical manifestations of Cushing Syndrome.
  • • Skin changes
  • • Facial changes : A rounded face is often described as a "moon face".
  • • Facial changes
  • • Fat deposition : Increased fat in the cervical spine area, known as a ‘buffalo hump’.
  • • Fat deposition
  • • Hypertension and hyperglycemia : Common consequences of chronic exposure to high levels of cortisol.
  • • Hypertension and hyperglycemia
  • • Elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol : This laboratory finding confirms the presence of excess cortisol, a hallmark of Cushing Syndrome.
  • • Elevated 24-hour urinary free cortisol
  • • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (Answer A) : While PCOS can be associated with obesity and menstrual irregularities, it does not typically present with the specific cushingoid features (such as easy bruising, skin thinning, and purple striae) or elevated cortisol levels.
  • • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) (Answer A)
  • • Adrenal Insufficiency (Answer C) : This condition is characterized by a deficiency in cortisol production, which contrasts with the elevated cortisol levels seen in this patient. Adrenal insufficiency typically presents with symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, and low blood pressure.
  • • Adrenal Insufficiency (Answer C)
  • • Primary Aldosteronism (Answer D) : This condition typically presents with hypertension and hypokalemia, but it is not associated with the cushingoid features or elevated cortisol levels found in this patient.
  • • Primary Aldosteronism (Answer D)
  • • The combination of the patient’s clinical presentation and the lab findings (especially the elevated urinary free cortisol) strongly points to Cushing Syndrome.

questions.text: A working mother in a multinational company brings her 3-months old child for a regular pediatric visit. As she has started to go to work after her child birth, she wants to feed her child with cow’s milk. She asks you that compared with cow’s milk, mother’s milk has which component in more quantity?
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Lactose.

questions.text: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except?

options.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

options.text: Increase in the rate of discharge of the y efferent neuron

options.label: C
options.text: Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool

options.label: D
